dict.string: Enables the guest account for login.

#!/bin/bash
testVariable=$(defaults read /Library/Preferences/com.apple.loginwindow.plist GuestEnabled)
if [ "$testVariable" == "1" ]; then
# Installed exit 1 else # Is not installed exit 0 fi

#!/bin/bash
# Enable the guest account ## Unfortunately, this only cosmetically changes what shows in System Preferences. It does not actually enable the guest account. ## I have to figure out what goes on behind the scenes. sudo defaults write /Library/Preferences/com.apple.loginwindow GuestEnabled -bool TRUE ## Not helpful in terms of fully scripting, but if you're willing to do a payload, you can make one copy of the ##/private/var/db/dslocal/nodes/Default/users/Guest.plist file and distribute out to the client machine, and that should enable the ## account again.

#!/bin/bash
# Disable the guest account ## This changes cosmetically what shows up in System Preferences sudo defaults write /Library/Preferences/com.apple.loginwindow GuestEnabled -bool FALSE ## This actually disables the guest account from being able to log in sudo rm /private/var/db/dslocal/nodes/Default/users/Guest.plist
